content.text: Bash cp - Copy Files and Directories
Using the cp Command
The cp command is used to copy files and directories from one location to another
content.html: The cp command is used to copy files and directories from one location to another

content.text: It's like making a duplicate of your file or folder.
content.html: It's like making a duplicate of your file or folder.

content.text: Basic Usage
To copy a file, use cp source_file destination_file :
content.html: To copy a file, use cp source_file destination_file:

content.code_html: cp my_file.txt copy_of_my_file.txt

content.text: Options
The cp command has options to change how it works:
content.html: The cp command has options to change how it works:

content.text: -v Option: Verbose Mode
The -v option enables verbose mode, which displays the files being copied in the terminal.
content.html: The -v option enables verbose mode, which displays the files being copied in the terminal.

content.text: This is useful for tracking the copy process, especially when dealing with many files.
content.html: This is useful for tracking the copy process, especially when dealing with many files.

content.code_html:
cp -v my_file.txt copy_of_my_file.txt
'my_file.txt' -> 'copy_of_my_file.txt'

content.text: Copy Directories Recursively
The -r option lets you copy entire directories, including all files and subdirectories.
content.html: The -r option lets you copy entire directories, including all files and subdirectories.

content.code_html: cp -r images images2

content.text: Prompt Before Overwrite
The -i option will prompt you before overwriting files, helping you avoid accidental replacements.
content.html: The -i option will prompt you before overwriting files, helping you avoid accidental replacements.

content.code:
cp
-i my_file.txt copy_of_my_file.txt
cp: overwrite copy_of_my_file.txt?
content.code_html:
cp -i my_file.txt copy_of_my_file.txt
cp: overwrite copy_of_my_file.txt?

content.text: Copy Only Newer Files
The -u option copies files only if the source file is newer than the destination file.
content.html: The -u option copies files only if the source file is newer than the destination file.

content.code_html: cp -u new_file.txt existing_file.txt

content.text: Using cp with Wildcards
Wildcards allow you to copy multiple files at once. For example, cp *.txt /destination/ will copy all text files to the destination folder.
content.html: Wildcards allow you to copy multiple files at once. For example, cp *.txt /destination/ will copy all text files to the destination folder.

content.code_html: cp *.txt /destination/
